speech.line: When I dissuaded him from his intent,
And found him pight to do it, with curst speech
I threaten’d to discover him; he replied,
“Thou unpossessing bastard, dost thou think,
If I would stand against thee, would the reposal
Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee
Make thy words faith’d? No. What I should deny
(As this I would, ay, though thou didst produce
My very character), I’ld turn it all
To thy suggestion, plot, and damned practice;
And thou must make a dullard of the world
If they not thought the profits of my death
Were very pregnant and potential spirits
To make thee seek it.”

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: O strange and fast’ned villain!
Would he deny his letter, said he? I never got him.
Hark, the Duke’s trumpets! I know not why he comes.
All ports I’ll bar, the villain shall not scape;
The Duke must grant me that. Besides, his picture
I will send far and near, that all the kingdom
May have due note of him, and of my land,
Loyal and natural boy, I’ll work the means
To make thee capable.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: How now, my noble friend? Since I came hither
(Which I can call but now) I have heard strange news.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: If it be true, all vengeance comes too short
Which can pursue th’ offender. How dost, my lord?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: O madam, my old heart is crack’d, it’s crack’d!

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: What, did my father’s godson seek your life?
He whom my father nam’d, your Edgar?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: O lady, lady, shame would have it hid!

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Was he not companion with the riotous knights
That tended upon my father?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I know not, madam. ’Tis too bad, too bad.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: Yes, madam, he was of that consort.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: No marvel then, though he were ill affected:
’Tis they have put him on the old man’s death,
To have th’ expense and waste of his revenues.
I have this present evening from my sister
Been well inform’d of them, and with such cautions,
That if they come to sojourn at my house,
I’ll not be there.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Nor I, assure thee, Regan.
Edmund, I hear that you have shown your father
A child-like office.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: It was my duty, sir.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: He did bewray his practice, and receiv’d
This hurt you see, striving to apprehend him.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Is he pursued?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Ay, my good lord.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: If he be taken, he shall never more
Be fear’d of doing harm. Make your own purpose,
How in my strength you please. For you, Edmund,
Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant
So much commend itself, you shall be ours.
Natures of such deep trust we shall much need;
You we first seize on.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: I shall serve you, sir,
Truly, however else.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: For him I thank your Grace.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: You know not why we came to visit you?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Thus out of season, threading dark-ey’d night:
Occasions, noble Gloucester, of some prize,
Wherein we must have use of your advice.
Our father he hath writ, so hath our sister,
Of differences, which I best thought it fit
To answer from our home; the several messengers
From hence attend dispatch. Our good old friend,
Lay comforts to your bosom, and bestow
Your needful counsel to our businesses,
Which craves the instant use.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I serve you, madam.
Your Graces are right welcome.

scene.scenepersonae: (Kent, Oswald, Edmund, Cornwall, Regan, Gloucester, Servants)
scene.scenedescription: Oswald arrives; not recognizing Kent, he takes him for one of Gloucester’s servants and asks where he can put his horse. Kent roundly insults him, and the two come to blows. Edmund attempts to stop the quarrel, but Kent turns on him. Gloucester and Cornwall appear and demand to know the cause for the fight. Kent refuses to do much more than insult Oswald, trying Cornwall’s patience until the Duke explodes and sentences Kent to the stocks. Gloucester disapproves of stocking the King’s messenger, but Cornwall is obdurate, and takes it on his own head. Gloucester apologizes to Kent, who tells him not to worry. Left alone, Kent rereads a letter he has received from Cordelia, whom he has informed of his disguise.
scene.stagedir: Enter Kent disguised as Caius and Steward Oswald severally.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Good dawning to thee, friend. Art of this house?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Ay.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Where may we set our horses?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: I’ th’ mire.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Prithee, if thou lov’st me, tell me.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: I love thee not.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Why then I care not for thee.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold, I would make thee care for me.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Why dost thou use me thus? I know thee not.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Fellow, I know thee.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: What dost thou know me for?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: A knave, a rascal, an eater of broken meats; a base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited, hundred-pound, filthy worsted-stocking knave ; a lily-liver’d, action-taking, whoreson, glass-gazing, superserviceable, finical rogue; one-trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a bawd in way of good service, and art nothing but the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pandar, and the son and heir of a mungril bitch; one whom I will beat into clamorous whining, if thou deni’st the least syllable of thy addition.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail on one that is neither known of thee nor knows thee?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: What a brazen-fac’d varlet art thou, to deny thou knowest me? Is it two days since I tripp’d up thy heels, and beat thee before the King? Draw, you rogue, for though it be night, yet the moon shines;
I’ll make a sop o’ th’ moonshine of you, you whoreson cullionly barber-monger, draw!

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Away, I have nothing to do with thee.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Draw, you rascal! You come with letters against the King, and take Vanity the puppet’s part against the royalty of her father. Draw, you rogue, or I’ll so carbonado your shanks! Draw, you rascal! Come your ways.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Help ho! Murder, help!

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Strike, you slave! Stand, rogue, stand, you neat slave! Strike!

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Help ho! Murder, murder!

scene.stagedir: Enter Bastard Edmund, with his rapier drawn.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: How now, what’s the matter? Part!

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: With you, goodman boy, and you please! Come, I’ll flesh ye, come on, young master.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Weapons? Arms? What’s the matter here?

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Keep peace, upon your lives!
He dies that strikes again. What is the matter?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: The messengers from our sister and the King.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: What is your difference? Speak.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: I am scarce in breath, my lord.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: No marvel, you have so bestirr’d your valor. You cowardly rascal, Nature disclaims in thee: a tailor made thee.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Thou art a strange fellow. A tailor make a man?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: A tailor, sir; a stone-cutter or a painter could not have made him so ill, though they had been but two years o’ th’ trade.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Speak yet, how grew your quarrel?

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life I have spar’d at suit of his grey beard—

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Thou whoreson zed, thou unnecessary letter! My lord, if you’ll give me leave, I will tread this unbolted villain into mortar, and daub the wall of a jakes with him. Spare my grey beard, you wagtail?

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Peace, sirrah!
You beastly knave, know you no reverence?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Yes, sir, but anger hath a privilege.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Why art thou angry?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: That such a slave as this should wear a sword,
Who wears no honesty. Such smiling rogues as these,
Like rats, oft bite the holy cords a-twain
Which are t’ intrinse t’ unloose; smooth every passion
That in the natures of their lords rebel,
Being oil to fire, snow to the colder moods;
Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks
With every gale and vary of their masters,
Knowing nought (like dogs) but following.
A plague upon your epileptic visage!
Smile you my speeches, as I were a fool?
Goose, and I had you upon Sarum plain,
I’ld drive ye cackling home to Camelot.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: What, art thou mad, old fellow?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: How fell you out? Say that.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: No contraries hold more antipathy
Than I and such a knave.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Why dost thou call him knave? What is his fault?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: His countenance likes me not.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: No more, perchance, does mine, nor his, nor hers.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Sir, ’tis my occupation to be plain:
I have seen better faces in my time
Than stands on any shoulder that I see
Before me at this instant.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: This is some fellow
Who, having been prais’d for bluntness, doth affect
A saucy roughness, and constrains the garb
Quite from his nature. He cannot flatter, he,
An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth!
And they will take’t, so; if not, he’s plain.
These kind of knaves I know, which in this plainness
Harbor more craft and more corrupter ends
Than twenty silly-ducking observants
That stretch their duties nicely.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Sir, in good faith, in sincere verity,
Under th’ allowance of your great aspect,
Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire
On flick’ring Phoebus’ front—

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: What mean’st by this?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much. I know, sir, I am no flatterer. He that beguil’d you in a plain accent was a plain knave, which for my part I will not be, though I should win your displeasure to entreat me to’t.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: What was th’ offense you gave him?

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: I never gave him any.
It pleas’d the King his master very late
To strike at me upon his misconstruction,
When he, compact, and flattering his displeasure,
Tripp’d me behind; being down, insulted, rail’d,
And put upon him such a deal of man
That worthied him, got praises of the King
For him attempting who was self-subdued,
And in the fleshment of this dread exploit,
Drew on me here again.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: None of these rogues and cowards
But Ajax is their fool.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Fetch forth the stocks!
You stubborn ancient knave, you reverent braggart,
We’ll teach you.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Sir, I am too old to learn.
Call not your stocks for me, I serve the King,
On whose employment I was sent to you.
You shall do small respects, show too bold malice
Against the grace and person of my master,
Stocking his messenger.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Fetch forth the stocks! As I have life and honor,
There shall he sit till noon.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Till noon? Till night, my lord, and all night too.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Why, madam, if I were your father’s dog,
You should not use me so.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Sir, being his knave, I will.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: This is a fellow of the self-same color
Our sister speaks of. Come, bring away the stocks!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Let me beseech your Grace not to do so.
His fault is much, and the good King his master
Will check him for’t. Your purpos’d low correction
Is such as basest and contemned’st wretches
For pilf’rings and most common trespasses
Are punish’d with. The King must take it ill
That he, so slightly valued in his messenger,
Should have him thus restrained.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: I’ll answer that.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: My sister may receive it much more worse
To have her gentleman abus’d, assaulted,
For following her affairs. Put in his legs.
speech.stagedir: Kent is put in the stocks.
speech.line: Come, my good lord, away.

scene.stagedir: Exit with all but Gloucester and Kent.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I am sorry for thee, friend, ’tis the Duke’s pleasure,
Whose disposition, all the world well knows,
Will not be rubb’d nor stopp’d. I’ll entreat for thee.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Pray do not, sir. I have watch’d and travell’d hard:
Some time I shall sleep out, the rest I’ll whistle.
A good man’s fortune may grow out at heels.
Give you good morrow!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: The Duke’s to blame in this, ’twill be ill taken.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Good King, that must approve the common saw,
Thou out of heaven’s benediction com’st
To the warm sun!
Approach, thou beacon to this under globe,
That by thy comfortable beams I may
Peruse this letter. Nothing almost sees miracles
But misery. I know ’tis from Cordelia,
Who hath most fortunately been inform’d
Of my obscured course;

line.recite: From this enormous state—seeking to give

speech.line: All weary and o’erwatch’d,
Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold
This shameful lodging.
Fortune, good night; smile once more, turn thy wheel.

scene.scenedescription: Edgar, tracked throughout the kingdom, decides to disguise himself as a mad, filthy beggar in hopes of escaping.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: I heard myself proclaim’d,
And by the happy hollow of a tree
Escap’d the hunt. No port is free, no place
That guard and most unusual vigilance
Does not attend my taking. Whiles I may scape
I will preserve myself, and am bethought
To take the basest and most poorest shape
That ever penury, in contempt of man,
Brought near to beast. My face I’ll grime with filth,
Blanket my loins, elf all my hairs in knots,
And with presented nakedness outface
The winds and persecutions of the sky.
The country gives me proof and president
Of Bedlam beggars, who, with roaring voices,
Strike in their numb’d and mortified arms
Pins, wooden pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary;
And with this horrible object, from low farms,
Poor pelting villages, sheep-cotes, and mills,
Sometimes with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers,
Enforce their charity. Poor Turlygod! Poor Tom!
That’s something yet: Edgar I nothing am.

scene.scenepersonae: (Lear, Fool, First Gentleman, Kent, Gloucester, Cornwall, Regan, Gloucester, Servants, Oswald, Goneril)
scene.scenedescription: Lear and his retinue arrive at Gloucester’s. The King finds it odd that Regan and Cornwall decided to leave their castle just as they heard of his approach, and that Kent has not returned. Kent salutes him from the stocks, and Lear is incensed at the insult, though he at first refuses to believe that Regan and Cornwall are responsible. Lear feels himself on the verge of losing control. Kent and the Fool banter as the King asks to see his daughter and son-in-law, but the latter two refuse, as they are exceedingly tired. Lear tries desperately to keep control of his increasingly demented temper. When Regan and Cornwall finally appear, Lear appeals to his daughter, weeping over Goneril’s bad treatment of him, but is shocked when Regan refuses to share his opinion. He attempts to reassure himself that she will never treat him the way Goneril did, but at that moment Goneril herself arrives, and the two sisters band together. Regan refuses to take Lear in, making the eminently reasonable point that she is not prepared to receive him; Goneril refuses to take him back unless he dismisses fifty of his knights. Between them they whittle down the number of knights he should be allowed, until they refuse to take any followers with him. His powerlessness brought home to him, Lear tries desperately not to weep. He stalks off with the Fool, despite the coming storm. Gloucester is worried about him, but the two sisters and Cornwall prevent him from helping the King. Cornwall coldly orders that the doors be barred against the storm, trapping Lear outside.
scene.stagedir: Enter Lear, Fool, and First Gentleman. Kent, disguised as Caius, in the stocks.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: ’Tis strange that they should so depart from home,
And not send back my messenger.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: As I learn’d,
The night before there was no purpose in them
Of this remove.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Hail to thee, noble master!

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Ha?
Mak’st thou this shame thy pastime?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: No, my lord.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Hah, ha, he wears cruel garters. Horses are tied by the heads, dogs and bears by th’ neck, monkeys by th’ loins, and men by th’ legs. When a man’s overlusty at legs, then he wears wooden nether-stocks.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: What’s he that hath so much thy place mistook
To set thee here?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: It is both he and she,
Your son and daughter.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: No, I say.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: I say yea.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: No, no, they would not.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Yes, they have.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: By Jupiter, I swear no.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: By Juno, I swear ay.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: They durst not do’t;
They could not, would not do’t. ’Tis worse than murder
To do upon respect such violent outrage.
Resolve me with all modest haste which way
Thou mightst deserve, or they impose, this usage,
Coming from us.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: My lord, when at their home
I did commend your Highness’ letters to them,
Ere I was risen from the place that showed
My duty kneeling, came there a reeking post,
Stew’d in his haste, half breathless, panting forth
From Goneril his mistress salutations;
Deliver’d letters, spite of intermission,
Which presently they read; on those contents
They summon’d up their meiny, straight took horse,
Commanded me to follow, and attend
The leisure of their answer, gave me cold looks:
And meeting here the other messenger,
Whose welcome I perceiv’d had poison’d mine—
Being the very fellow which of late
Display’d so saucily against your Highness—
Having more man than wit about me, drew.
He rais’d the house with loud and coward cries.
Your son and daughter found this trespass worth
The shame which here it suffers.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Winter’s not gone yet, if the wild geese fly that way.
Fathers that wear rags
Do make their children blind,
But fathers that bear bags
Shall see their children kind.
Fortune, that arrant whore,
ne’er turns the key to th’ poor.
But for all this, thou shalt have as many dolors for thy daughters as thou canst tell in a year.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: O how this mother swells up toward my heart!
Hysterica passio, down, thou climbing sorrow,
Thy element’s below.—Where is this daughter?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: With the Earl, sir, here within.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Follow me not,
Stay here.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: Made you no more offense but what you speak of?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: None.
How chance the King comes with so small a number?

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: And thou hadst been set i’ th’ stocks for that question, thou’dst well deserv’d it.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Why, Fool?

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: We’ll set thee to school to an ant, to teach thee there’s no laboring i’ th’ winter. All that follow their noses are led by their eyes but blind men, and there’s not a nose among twenty but can smell him that’s stinking. Let go thy hold when a great wheel runs down a hill, lest it break thy neck with following; but the great one that goes upward, let him draw thee after. When a wise man gives thee better counsel, give me mine again, I would have none but knaves follow it, since a fool gives it.
That sir which serves and seeks for gain,
And follows but for form,
Will pack when it begins to rain,
And leave thee in the storm.
But I will tarry, the Fool will stay,
And let the wise man fly.
The knave turns fool that runs away,
The Fool no knave, perdie.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Where learn’d you this, Fool?

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Not i’ th’ stocks, fool.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Deny to speak with me? They are sick? They are weary?
They have travell’d all the night? Mere fetches,
The images of revolt and flying off.
Fetch me a better answer.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: My dear lord,
You know the fiery quality of the Duke,
How unremovable and fix’d he is
In his own course.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Vengeance! Plague! Death! Confusion!
Fiery? What quality? Why, Gloucester, Gloucester,
I’ld speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Well, my good lord, I have inform’d them so.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Inform’d them? Dost thou understand me, man?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Ay, my good lord.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: The King would speak with Cornwall, the dear father
Would with his daughter speak, commands, tends service.
Are they inform’d of this? My breath and blood!
Fiery? The fiery Duke? Tell the hot Duke that—
No, but not yet, may be he is not well:
Infirmity doth still neglect all office
Whereto our health is bound; we are not ourselves
When nature, being oppress’d, commands the mind
To suffer with the body. I’ll forbear,
And am fallen out with my more headier will,
To take the indispos’d and sickly fit
For the sound man.
Death on my state! Wherefore
Should he sit here? This act persuades me
That this remotion of the Duke and her
Is practice only. Give me my servant forth.
Go tell the Duke, and ’s wife, I’ld speak with them—
Now, presently. Bid them come forth and hear me,
Or at their chamber-door I’ll beat the drum
Till it cry sleep to death.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I would have all well betwixt you.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: O me, my heart! My rising heart! But down!

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Cry to it, nuncle, as the cockney did to the eels when she put ’em i’ th’ paste alive; she knapp’d ’em o’ th’ coxcombs with a stick, and cried, “Down, wantons, down!” ’Twas her brother that, in pure kindness to his horse, butter’d his hay.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Good morrow to you both.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Hail to your Grace!

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: I am glad to see your Highness.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Regan, I think you are; I know what reason
I have to think so. If thou shouldst not be glad,
I would divorce me from thy mother’s tomb,
Sepulchring an adult’ress.
O, are you free?
Some other time for that.
Beloved Regan,
Thy sister’s naught. O Regan, she hath tied
Sharp-tooth’d unkindness, like a vulture, here.
I can scarce speak to thee; thou’lt not believe
With how deprav’d a quality—O Regan!

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: I pray you, sir, take patience. I have hope
You less know how to value her desert
Than she to scant her duty.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Say? How is that?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: I cannot think my sister in the least
Would fail her obligation. If, sir, perchance
She have restrain’d the riots of your followers,
’Tis on such ground and to such wholesome end
As clears her from all blame.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: My curses on her!

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: O sir, you are old,
Nature in you stands on the very verge
Of his confine. You should be rul’d and led
By some discretion that discerns your state
Better than you yourself. Therefore I pray you
That to our sister you do make return.
Say you have wrong’d her.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Ask her forgiveness?
Do you but mark how this becomes the house!
“Dear daughter, I confess that I am old;
Age is unnecessary. On my knees I beg
That You’ll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food.”

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Good sir, no more; these are unsightly tricks.
Return you to my sister.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Never, Regan:
She hath abated me of half my train;
Look’d black upon me, strook me with her tongue,
Most serpent-like, upon the very heart.
All the stor’d vengeances of heaven fall
On her ingrateful top! Strike her young bones,
You taking airs, with lameness!

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Fie, sir, fie!

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames
Into her scornful eyes! Infect her beauty,
You fen-suck’d fogs, drawn by the pow’rful sun,
To fall and blister!

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: O the blest gods! So
Will you wish on me, when the rash mood is on.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: No, Regan, thou shalt never have my curse.
Thy tender-hefted nature shall not give
Thee o’er to harshness. Her eyes are fierce, but thine
Do comfort, and not burn. ’Tis not in thee
To grudge my pleasures, to cut off my train,
To bandy hasty words, to scant my sizes,
And in conclusion to oppose the bolt
Against my coming in. Thou better know’st
The offices of nature, bond of childhood,
Effects of courtesy, dues of gratitude:
Thy half o’ th’ kingdom hast thou not forgot,
Wherein I thee endow’d.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Good sir, to th’ purpose.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Who put my man i’ th’ stocks?

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: What trumpet’s that?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: I know’t, my sister’s. This approves her letter,
That she would soon be here.
Is your lady come?

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: This is a slave whose easy-borrowed pride
Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows.
Out, varlet, from my sight!

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: What means your Grace?

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Who stock’d my servant? Regan, I have good hope
Thou didst not know on’t. Who comes here? O heavens!
If you do love old men, if your sweet sway
Allow obedience, if you yourselves are old,
Make it your cause; send down, and take my part.
Art not asham’d to look upon this beard?
O Regan, will you take her by the hand?

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: Why not by th’ hand, sir? How have I offended?
All’s not offense that indiscretion finds
And dotage terms so.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: O sides, you are too tough!
Will you yet hold? How came my man i’ th’ stocks?

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: I set him there, sir; but his own disorders
Deserv’d much less advancement.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: You? Did you?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: I pray you, father, being weak, seem so.
If till the expiration of your month
You will return and sojourn with my sister,
Dismissing half your train, come then to me.
I am now from home, and out of that provision
Which shall be needful for your entertainment.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Return to her? And fifty men dismiss’d?
No, rather I abjure all roofs, and choose
To wage against the enmity o’ th’ air,
To be a comrade with the wolf and owl—
Necessity’s sharp pinch. Return with her?
Why, the hot-bloodied France, that dowerless took
Our youngest born, I could as well be brought
To knee his throne, and squire-like, pension beg
To keep base life afoot. Return with her?
Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter
To this detested groom.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: At your choice, sir.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad.
I will not trouble thee, my child; farewell:
We’ll no more meet, no more see one another.
But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter—
Or rather a disease that’s in my flesh,
Which I must needs call mine. Thou art a bile,
A plague-sore, or embossed carbuncle,
In my corrupted blood. But I’ll not chide thee,
Let shame come when it will, I do not call it.
I do not bid the thunder—bearer shoot,
Nor tell tales of thee to high—judging Jove.
Mend when thou canst, be better at thy leisure,
I can be patient, I can stay with Regan,
I and my hundred knights.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Not altogether so,
I look’d not for you yet, nor am provided
For your fit welcome. Give ear, sir, to my sister,
For those that mingle reason with your passion
Must be content to think you old, and so—
But she knows what she does.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Is this well spoken?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: I dare avouch it, sir. What, fifty followers?
Is it not well? What should you need of more?
Yea, or so many? Sith that both charge and danger
Speak ’gainst so great a number? How in one house
Should many people under two commands
Hold amity? ’Tis hard, almost impossible.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: Why might not you, my lord, receive attendance
From those that she calls servants or from mine?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Why not, my lord? If then they chanc’d to slack ye,
We could control them. If you will come to me
(For now I spy a danger), I entreat you
To bring but five and twenty; to no more
Will I give place or notice.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: I gave you all—

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: And in good time you gave it.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Made you my guardians, my depositaries,
But kept a reservation to be followed
With such a number. What, must I come to you
With five and twenty? Regan, said you so?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: And speak’t again, my lord, no more with me.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Those wicked creatures yet do look well-favor’d
When others are more wicked; not being the worst
Stands in some rank of praise.
I’ll go with thee,
Thy fifty yet doth double five and twenty,
And thou art twice her love.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: Hear me, my lord:
What need you five and twenty? Ten? Or five?
To follow in a house where twice so many
Have a command to tend you?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: What need one?

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: O, reason not the need! Our basest beggars
Are in the poorest thing superfluous.
Allow not nature more than nature needs,
Man’s life is cheap as beast’s. Thou art a lady;
If only to go warm were gorgeous,
Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear’st,
Which scarcely keeps thee warm. But for true need—
You heavens, give me that patience, patience I need!
You see me here, you gods, a poor old man,
As full of grief as age, wretched in both.
If it be you that stirs these daughters’ hearts
Against their father, fool me not so much
To bear it tamely; touch me with noble anger,
And let not women’s weapons, water-drops,
Stain my man’s cheeks! No, you unnatural hags,
I will have such revenges on you both
That all the world shall—I will do such things—
What they are yet I know not, but they shall be
The terrors of the earth! You think I’ll weep:
No, I’ll not weep.
I have full cause of weeping, but this heart
Storm and tempest.
Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws
Or ere I’ll weep. O Fool, I shall go mad!

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Lear, Gloucester, First Gentleman, and Fool.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Let us withdraw, ’twill be a storm.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: This house is little, the old man and ’s people
Cannot be well bestow’d.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: ’Tis his own blame hath put himself from rest,
And must needs taste his folly.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: For his particular, I’ll receive him gladly,
But not one follower.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: So am I purpos’d.
Where is my Lord of Gloucester?

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Followed the old man forth.
He is return’d.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: The King is in high rage.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Whither is he going?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: He calls to horse, but will I know not whither.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: ’Tis best to give him way, he leads himself.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: My lord, entreat him by no means to stay.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Alack, the night comes on, and the bleak winds
Do sorely ruffle; for many miles about
There’s scarce a bush.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: O sir, to willful men,
The injuries that they themselves procure
Must be their schoolmasters. Shut up your doors.
He is attended with a desperate train,
And what they may incense him to, being apt
To have his ear abus’d, wisdom bids fear.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Shut up your doors, my lord, ’tis a wild night,
My Regan counsels well. Come out o’ th’ storm.

scene.scenedescription: Kent meets a gentleman of the king’s court, who informs him of Lear’s wild, grief-stricken ravings, and that the King is accompanied now only by the Fool. Kent in turn tells him that the French have set foot on Britain’s shores, and asks him to go to Dover to tell Cordelia just how Lear has been treated.
scene.stagedir: Storm still. Enter Kent disguised as Caius and First Gentleman severally.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Who’s there, besides foul weather?

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: One minded like the weather, most unquietly.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: I know you. Where’s the King?

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: Contending with the fretful elements;
Bids the wind blow the earth into the sea,
Or swell the curled waters ’bove the main,
That things might change or cease, tears his white hair,
Which the impetuous blasts with eyeless rage
Catch in their fury, and make nothing of,
Strives in his little world of man to outscorn
The to-and-fro-conflicting wind and rain.
This night, wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch,
The lion and the belly-pinched wolf
Keep their fur dry, unbonneted he runs,
And bids what will take all.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: But who is with him?

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: None but the Fool, who labors to outjest
His heart-strook injuries.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Sir, I do know you,
And dare upon the warrant of my note
Commend a dear thing to you. There is division
(Although as yet the face of it is cover’d
With mutual cunning) ’twixt Albany and Cornwall;
Who have—as who have not, that their great stars
Thron’d and set high?—servants, who seem no less,
Which are to France the spies and speculations
Intelligent of our state. What hath been seen,
Either in snuffs and packings of the Dukes,
Or the hard rein which both of them hath borne
Against the old kind King; or something deeper,
Whereof (perchance) these are but furnishings—
But true it is, from France there comes a power
Into this scattered kingdom, who already
Wise in our negligence, have secret feet
In some of our best ports, and are at point
To show their open banner. Now to you:
If on my credit you dare build so far
To make your speed to Dover, you shall find
Some that will thank you, making just report
Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow
The King hath cause to plain.
I am a gentleman of blood and breeding,
And from some knowledge and assurance, offer
This office to you.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: I will talk further with you.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: No, do not.
For confirmation that I am much more
Than my out-wall, open this purse and take
What it contains. If you shall see Cordelia
(As fear not but you shall), show her this ring,
And she will tell you who that fellow is
That yet you do not know. Fie on this storm!
I will go seek the King.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: Give me your hand. Have you no more to say?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Few words, but to effect, more than all yet:
That when we have found the King—in which your pain
That way, I’ll this—he that first lights on him
Holla the other.

scene.scenedescription: Lear raves against the storm, comparing it favorably to his daughters, since he never did anything for the storm. The Fool begs him to take shelter. Kent finds them, and is horrified to see that Lear has lost his grip on reality. He convinces Lear to go into a hovel, and for the first time Lear shows a trace of kindness for another human being, asking the Fool how he is. Lear and the fool are roaming about. Lear is defying the hurricane. Kent finds the odd pair and urges Lear to seek shelter. They go into a near-by hovel.
scene.stagedir: Storm still. Enter Lear and Fool.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! Rage, blow!
You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout
Till you have drench’d our steeples, drown’d the cocks!
You sulph’rous and thought-executing fires,
Vaunt-couriers of oak-cleaving thunderbolts,
Singe my white head! And thou, all-shaking thunder,
Strike flat the thick rotundity o’ th’ world!
Crack nature’s moulds, all germains spill at once
That makes ingrateful man!

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: O nuncle, court holy-water in a dry house is better than this rain-water out o’ door. Good nuncle, in, ask thy daughters blessing. Here’s a night pities neither wise men nor fools.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Rumble thy bellyful! Spit, fire! Spout, rain!
Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire are my daughters.
I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness;
I never gave you kingdom, call’d you children;
You owe me no subscription. Then let fall
Your horrible pleasure. Here I stand your slave,
A poor, infirm, weak, and despis’d old man;
But yet I call you servile ministers,
That will with two pernicious daughters join
Your high-engender’d battles ’gainst a head
So old and white as this. O, ho! ’Tis foul.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: He that has a house to put ’s head in has a good head-piece.
The codpiece that will house
Before the head has any,
The head and he shall louse:
So beggars marry many.
The man that makes his toe
What he his heart should make,
Shall of a corn cry woe,
And turn his sleep to wake.
For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths in a glass.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: No, I will be the pattern of all patience, I will say nothing.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Marry, here’s grace and a codpiece—that’s a wise man and a fool.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Alas, sir, are you here? Things that love night
Love not such nights as these. The wrathful skies
Gallow the very wanderers of the dark,
And make them keep their caves. Since I was man,
Such sheets of fire, such bursts of horrid thunder,
Such groans of roaring wind and rain, I never
Remember to have heard. Man’s nature cannot carry
Th’ affliction nor the fear.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Let the great gods,
That keep this dreadful pudder o’er our heads,
Find out their enemies now. Tremble, thou wretch
That hast within thee undivulged crimes
Unwhipt of justice! Hide thee, thou bloody hand;
Thou perjur’d, and thou simular of virtue
That art incestuous! Caitiff, to pieces shake,
That under covert and convenient seeming
Has practic’d on man’s life! Close pent-up guilts,
Rive your concealing continents, and cry
These dreadful summoners grace. I am a man
More sinn’d against than sinning.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Alack, bare-headed?
Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel,
Some friendship will it lend you ’gainst the tempest.
Repose you there, while I to this hard house
(More harder than the stones whereof ’tis rais’d,
Which even but now, demanding after you,
Denied me to come in) return, and force
Their scanted courtesy.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: My wits begin to turn.
Come on, my boy. How dost, my boy? Art cold?
I am cold myself. Where is this straw, my fellow?
The art of our necessities is strange
And can make vild things precious. Come, your hovel.
Poor Fool and knave, I have one part in my heart
That’s sorry yet for thee.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: “He that has and a little tiny wit—
With heigh-ho, the wind and the rain—
Must make content with his fortunes fit,
Though the rain it raineth every day.”

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: True, boy. Come bring us to this hovel.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: This is a brave night to cool a courtezan. I’ll speak a prophecy ere I go:
When priests are more in word than matter;
When brewers mar their malt with water;
When nobles are their tailors’ tutors;
No heretics burn’d, but wenches’ suitors;
Then shall the realm of Albion
Come to great confusion.
When every case in law is right;
No squire in debt, nor no poor knight;
When slanders do not live in tongues;
Nor cutpurses come not to throngs;
When usurers tell their gold i’ th’ field,
And bawds and whores do churches build;
Then comes the time, who lives to see’t,
That going shall be us’d with feet.
This prophecy Merlin shall make, for I live before his time.

scene.scenedescription: Gloucester bemoans to Edmund that Cornwall and Regan took away his command over his own house for speaking pityingly of Lear, whom they strictly forbid him to help. He tells Edmund that there are rumors of a rift between Cornwall and Albany, as well as that the French have landed. Gloucester also mysteriously says that Lear will be revenged, as a letter he has hidden away proves. Edmund immediately resolves to tell Cornwall this.
scene.stagedir: Enter Gloucester and Edmund with lights.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural dealing. When I desir’d their leave that I might pity him, they took from me the use of mine own house, charg’d me on pain of perpetual displeasure neither to speak of him, entreat for him, or any way sustain him.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: Most savage and unnatural!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Go to; say you nothing. There is division between the Dukes, and a worse matter than that. I have receiv’d a letter this night—’tis dangerous to be spoken; I have lock’d the letter in my closet. These injuries the King now bears will be reveng’d home; there is part of a power already footed: we must incline to the King. I will look him and privily relieve him. Go you and maintain talk with the Duke, that my charity be not of him perceiv’d. If he ask for me, I am ill and gone to bed. If I die for’t (as no less is threat’ned me), the King my old master must be reliev’d. There is strange things toward, Edmund, pray you be careful.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the Duke
Instantly know, and of that letter too.
This seems a fair deserving, and must draw me
That which my father loses: no less than all.
The younger rises when the old doth fall.

scene.scenedescription: Kent has a hard time persuading Lear to enter the hovel, as the King is too busy ruminating on his wrongs. In the end he insists that the Fool go first, while he takes pity on the homeless of the world. Edgar, disguised as the mad Poor Tom, suddenly emerges from the hovel, almost naked and gabbling nonsense. Lear insists that Poor Tom could only have been brought so low by his daughters’ mistreatment. Looking at the beggar, it occurs to him that this is all man is, and to match him Lear tears off his clothes. Gloucester enters, and Edgar pretends to think him a devil; the old man fails to recognize his son, just as Lear did not recognize his godson. Gloucester begs Lear to follow him somewhere warm, despite Regan’s prohibition. Lear agrees to go, but insists that Poor Tom accompany him.
scene.stagedir: Enter Lear, Kent disguised as Caius, and Fool.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Here is the place, my lord; good my lord, enter,
The tyranny of the open night’s too rough
For nature to endure.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Let me alone.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Good my lord, enter here.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Wilt break my heart?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: I had rather break mine own. Good my lord, enter.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Thou think’st ’tis much that this contentious storm
Invades us to the skin; so ’tis to thee;
But where the greater malady is fix’d,
The lesser is scarce felt. Thou’dst shun a bear,
But if thy flight lay toward the roaring sea,
Thou’dst meet the bear i’ th’ mouth. When the mind’s free,
The body’s delicate; this tempest in my mind
Doth from my senses take all feeling else,
Save what beats there—filial ingratitude!
Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand
For lifting food to’t? But I will punish home.
No, I will weep no more. In such a night
To shut me out? Pour on, I will endure.
In such a night as this? O Regan, Goneril!
Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all—
O, that way madness lies, let me shun that!
No more of that.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Good my lord, enter here.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Prithee go in thyself, seek thine own ease.
This tempest will not give me leave to ponder
On things would hurt me more. But I’ll go in.
In, boy, go first.—You houseless poverty—
Nay, get thee in; I’ll pray, and then I’ll sleep.
Poor naked wretches, wheresoe’er you are,
That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm,
How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides,
Your loop’d and window’d raggedness, defend you
From seasons such as these? O, I have ta’en
Too little care of this! Take physic, pomp,
Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel,
That thou mayst shake the superflux to them,
And show the heavens more just.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Fathom and half, fathom and half! Poor Tom!

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Come not in here, nuncle, here’s a spirit. Help me, help me!

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Give me thy hand. Who’s there?

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: A spirit, a spirit! He says his name’s poor Tom.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: What art thou that dost grumble there i’ th’ straw? Come forth.

scene.stagedir: Enter Edgar disguised as a madman.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Away, the foul fiend follows me! Through the sharp hawthorn blow the cold winds. Humh, go to thy bed and warm thee.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Didst thou give all to thy daughters? And art thou come to this?

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Who gives any thing to poor Tom? Whom the foul fiend hath led through fire and through flame, through ford and whirlpool, o’er bog and quagmire; that hath laid knives under his pillow, and halters in his pew, set ratsbane by his porridge, made him proud of heart, to ride on a bay trotting-horse over four-inch’d bridges, to course his own shadow for a traitor. Bless thy five wits! Tom’s a-cold—O do de, do de, do de. Bless thee from whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking! Do poor Tom some charity, whom the foul fiend vexes. There could I have him now—and there—and there again—and there.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Has his daughters brought him to this pass? Couldst thou save nothing? Wouldst thou give ’em all?

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Nay, he reserv’d a blanket, else we had been all sham’d.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air Hang fated o’er men’s faults light on thy daughters!

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: He hath no daughters, sir.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Death, traitor! Nothing could have subdu’d nature
To such a lowness but his unkind daughters.
Is it the fashion, that discarded fathers
Should have thus little mercy on their flesh?
Judicious punishment! ’Twas this flesh begot
Those pelican daughters.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Pillicock sat on Pillicock-Hill, alow! Alow, loo, loo!

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Take heed o’ th’ foul fiend. Obey thy parents, keep thy word’s justice, swear not, commit not with man’s sworn spouse, set not thy sweet heart on proud array. Tom’s a-cold.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: What hast thou been?

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: A servingman! Proud in heart and mind; that curl’d my hair; wore gloves in my cap; serv’d the lust of my mistress’ heart, and did the act of darkness with her; swore as many oaths as I spake words, and broke them in the sweet face of heaven: one that slept in the contriving of lust, and wak’d to do it. Wine lov’d I deeply, dice dearly; and in woman out-paramour’d the Turk. False of heart, light of ear, bloody of hand; hog in sloth, fox in stealth, wolf in greediness, dog in madness, lion in prey. Let not the creaking of shoes nor the rustling of silks betray thy poor heart to woman. Keep thy foot out of brothels, thy hand out of plackets, thy pen from lenders’ books, and defy the foul fiend. Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind: says suum, mun, nonny. Dolphin my boy, boy, sessa! Let him trot by.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Thou wert better in a grave than to answer with thy uncover’d body this extremity of the skies. Is man no more than this? Consider him well. Thou ow’st the worm no silk, the beast no hide, the sheep no wool, the cat no perfume. Ha? Here’s three on ’s are sophisticated. Thou art the thing itself: unaccommodated man is no more but such a poor, bare, fork’d animal as thou art. Off, off, you lendings! Come, unbutton here.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Prithee, nuncle, be contented, ’tis a naughty night to swim in. Now a little fire in a wild field were like an old lecher’s heart, a small spark, all the rest on ’s body cold.
Look, here comes a walking fire.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet; he begins at curfew, and walks till the first cock; he gives the web and the pin, squinies the eye, and makes the hare-lip; mildews the white wheat, and hurts the poor creature of earth.
Swithold footed thrice the ’old,
He met the night-mare and her nine-fold;
Bid her alight,
And her troth plight,
And aroint thee, witch, aroint thee!

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: How fares your Grace?

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: What’s he?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Who’s there? What is’t you seek?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: What are you there? Your names?

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Poor Tom, that eats the swimming frog, the toad, the todpole, the wall-newt, and the water; that in the fury of his heart, when the foul fiend rages, eats cow-dung for sallets; swallows the old rat and the ditch-dog; drinks the green mantle of the standing pool; who is whipt from tithing to tithing, and stock-punish’d and imprison’d; who hath had three suits to his back, six shirts to his body—
Horse to ride, and weapon to wear;
But mice and rats, and such small deer,
Have been Tom’s food for seven long year.
Beware my follower. Peace, Smulkin, peace, thou fiend!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: What, hath your Grace no better company?

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: The prince of darkness is a gentleman. Modo he’s call’d, and Mahu.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Our flesh and blood, my lord, is grown so vild
That it doth hate what gets it.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Poor Tom’s a-cold.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Go in with me; my duty cannot suffer
T’ obey in all your daughters’ hard commands.
Though their injunction be to bar my doors,
And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you,
Yet have I ventured to come seek you out,
And bring you where both fire and food is ready.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: First let me talk with this philosopher.
What is the cause of thunder?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Good my lord, take his offer, go into th’ house.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: I’ll talk a word with this same learned Theban.
What is your study?

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: How to prevent the fiend, and to kill vermin.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Let me ask you one word in private.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Importune him once more to go, my lord,
His wits begin t’ unsettle.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Canst thou blame him?
His daughters seek his death. Ah, that good Kent!
He said it would be thus, poor banish’d man.
Thou sayest the King grows mad, I’ll tell thee, friend,
I am almost mad myself. I had a son,
Now outlaw’d from my blood; he sought my life,
But lately, very late. I lov’d him, friend,
No father his son dearer; true to tell thee,
The grief hath craz’d my wits. What a night’s this!
I do beseech your Grace—

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: O, cry you mercy, sir.
Noble philosopher, your company.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Tom’s a-cold.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: In, fellow, there, into th’ hovel; keep thee warm.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Come, let’s in all.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: This way, my lord.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: With him;
I will keep still with my philosopher.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Good my lord, soothe him; let him take the fellow.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Take him you on.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Sirrah, come on; go along with us.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Come, good Athenian.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: No words, no words, hush.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Child Rowland to the dark tower came,
His word was still, “Fie, foh, and fum,
I smell the blood of a British man.”

scene.scenedescription: Edmund has shown Cornwall his father’s secret letter, and Cornwall is infuriated, swearing to be revenged on the old man. Edmund hypocritically laments the fight he had to hold between loyalty to his father and to his country. Cornwall names him Duke of Gloucester in his father’s stead.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: I will have my revenge ere I depart his house.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: How, my lord, I may be censur’d, that nature thus gives way to loyalty, something fears me to think of.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: I now perceive, it was not altogether your brother’s evil disposition made him seek his death; but a provoking merit, set a-work by a reprovable badness in himself.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: How malicious is my fortune, that I must repent to be just! This is the letter which he spoke of, which approves him an intelligent party to the advantages of France. O heavens! That this treason were not; or not I the detector!

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Go with me to the Duchess.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: If the matter of this paper be certain, you have mighty business in hand.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester. Seek out where thy father is, that he may be ready for our apprehension.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: If I find him comforting the King, it will stuff his suspicion more fully.—I will persever in my course of loyalty, though the conflict be sore between that and my blood.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: I will lay trust upon thee; and thou shalt find a dearer father in my love.

scene.scenelocation: A chamber in a farmhouse adjoining the castle.
scene.scenedescription: Gloucester brings Lear and his bedraggled retinue to a small farmhouse adjoining his castle, promising to return soon with things to make it more comfortable. Lear appoints Kent, the Fool and Edgar as judges and proceeds to hold a trial of his daughters for their ingratitude. Moved, Edgar finds it harder and harder to keep up his role. Kent tries to persuade Lear to sleep. Gloucester returns in a hurry, having overheard a plot against Lear’s life; he urges Kent to take the King towards Dover.
scene.stagedir: Enter Kent disguised as Caius and Gloucester.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Here is better than the open air, take it thankfully. I will piece out the comfort with what addition I can. I will not be long from you.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: All the pow’r of his wits have given way to his impatience. The gods reward your kindness!

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Frateretto calls me, and tells me Nero is an angler in the lake of darkness. Pray, innocent, and beware the foul fiend.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Prithee, nuncle, tell me whether a madman be a gentleman or a yeoman?

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: A king, a king!

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: No, he’s a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son; for he’s a mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: To have a thousand with red burning spits
Come hizzing in upon ’em—

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: The foul fiend bites my back.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: He’s mad that trusts in the tameness of a wolf, a horse’s health, a boy’s love, or a whore’s oath.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: It shall be done, I will arraign them straight.
Come sit thou here, most learned justicer;
Thou, sapient sir, sit here. Now, you she-foxes—

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Look where he stands and glares! Want’st thou eyes at trial, madam?
“Come o’er the bourn, Bessy, to me”—

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Her boat hath a leak,
And she must not speak
Why she dares not come over to thee.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: The foul fiend haunts poor Tom in the voice of a nightingale. Hoppedance cries in Tom’s belly for two white herring. Croak not, black angel, I have no food for thee.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: How do you, sir? Stand you not so amaz’d.
Will you lie down and rest upon the cushions?

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: I’ll see their trial first, bring in their evidence.
Thou robed man of justice, take thy place,
And thou, his yoke-fellow of equity,
Bench by his side.
You are o’ th’ commission,
Sit you too.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Let us deal justly.
Sleepest or wakest thou, jolly shepherd?
Thy sheep be in the corn,
And for one blast of thy minikin mouth,
Thy sheep shall take no harm.
Purr the cat is grey.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Arraign her first, ’tis Goneril. I here take my oath before this honorable assembly, she kick’d the poor king her father.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Come hither, mistress. Is your name Goneril?

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: She cannot deny it.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Cry you mercy, I took you for a join-stool.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: And here’s another, whose warp’d looks proclaim
What store her heart is made an. Stop her there!
Arms, arms, sword, fire! Corruption in the place!
False justicer, why hast thou let her scape?

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Bless thy five wits!

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: O pity! Sir, where is the patience now
That you so oft have boasted to retain?

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: My tears begin to take his part so much,
They mar my counterfeiting.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: The little dogs and all,
Trey, Blanch, and Sweetheart, see, they bark at me.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Tom will throw his head at them. Avaunt, you curs!
Be thy mouth or black or white,
Tooth that poisons if it bite;
Mastiff, greyhound, mongril grim,
Hound or spaniel, brach or lym,
Or bobtail tike or trundle-tail,
Tom will make him weep and wail,
For with throwing thus my head,
Dogs leapt the hatch, and all are fled.
Do de, de, de. Sessa! Come, march to wakes and fairs and market towns. Poor Tom, thy horn is dry.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Then let them anatomize Regan; see what breeds about her heart. Is there any cause in nature that make these hard hearts?
You, sir, I entertain for one of my hundred; only I do not like the fashion of your garments. You will say they are Persian, but let them be chang’d.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Now, good my lord, lie here and rest awhile.

speech.speaker: LEAR.
speech.line: Make no noise, make no noise, draw the curtains. So, so; we’ll go to supper i’ th’ morning.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: And I’ll go to bed at noon.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Come hither, friend; where is the King my master?

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Here, sir, but trouble him not—his wits are gone.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Good friend, I prithee take him in thy arms;
I have o’erheard a plot of death upon him.
There is a litter ready, lay him in’t,
And drive toward Dover, friend, where thou shalt meet
Both welcome and protection. Take up thy master;
If thou shouldst dally half an hour, his life,
With thine and all that offer to defend him,
Stand in assured loss. Take up, take up,
And follow me, that will to some provision
Give thee quick conduct.

speech.speaker: KENT.
speech.line: Oppressed nature sleeps.
This rest might yet have balm’d thy broken sinews,
Which, if convenience will not allow,
Stand in hard cure.
Come help to bear thy master;
Thou must not stay behind.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Come, come, away.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: When we our betters see bearing our woes,
We scarcely think our miseries our foes.
Who alone suffers, suffers most i’ th’ mind,
Leaving free things and happy shows behind,
But then the mind much sufferance doth o’erskip,
When grief hath mates, and bearing fellowship.
How light and portable my pain seems now,
When that which makes me bend makes the King bow:
He childed as I fathered! Tom, away!
Mark the high noises, and thyself bewray
When false opinion, whose wrong thoughts defile thee,
In thy just proof repeals and reconciles thee.
What will hap more tonight, safe scape the King!
Lurk, lurk.

scene.scenepersonae: (Cornwall, Regan, Goneril, Edmund, Servants, Oswald, Gloucester)
scene.scenedescription: Cornwell sends Goneril to warn Albany that the French army has landed, and tells Edmund to accompany her, to avoid his seeing what, exactly, is going to be done to Gloucester, whom servants have gone to seek. The sisters want him immediately punished. Oswald informs them that the King has been sent towards Dover. Gloucester is brought in, and Regan and Cornwall have him tied to a chair. They interrogate him about his links to France, pulling out the letter that Edmund told them about. Gloucester admits that he has communicated with them, but insists his correspondent was a neutral party. They do not believe him. Asked why he sent the King to Dover despite orders to the contrary, he finally bursts out how he wanted to protect Lear from his daughters. Cornwall puts out one of Gloucester’s eyes, and is about to do the other when his servant insist that he stop. Cornwall fights the servant, who wounds him, and Regan stabs the servant from behind. Despite his wound, Cornwall pulls out Gloucester’s other eye, and when he calls on Edmund for help, Regan informs him that it was Edmund who betrayed him. Just blinded, Gloucester sees the truth about his sons. The wounded Cornwall realizes that his wound is both serious and ill-timed. He orders that Gloucester be turned out. The servants decide to ask the madman to guide Gloucester. One of them dresses Gloucester’s wounded eyes.
scene.stagedir: Enter Cornwall, Regan, Goneril, Bastard Edmund, and Servants.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Post speedily to my lord your husband, show him this letter. The army of France is landed.—Seek out the traitor Gloucester.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Hang him instantly.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: Pluck out his eyes.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Leave him to my displeasure. Edmund, keep you our sister company; the revenges we are bound to take upon your traitorous father are not fit for your beholding. Advise the Duke, where you are going, to a most festinate preparation; we are bound to the like. Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us. Farewell, dear sister, farewell, my Lord of Gloucester.
How now? Where’s the King?

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: My Lord of Gloucester hath convey’d him hence.
Some five or six and thirty of his knights,
Hot questrists after him, met him at gate,
Who, with some other of the lord’s dependants,
Are gone with him toward Dover, where they boast
To have well-armed friends.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Get horses for your mistress.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: Farewell, sweet lord, and sister.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Edmund, farewell.
Go seek the traitor Gloucester,
Pinion him like a thief, bring him before us.
Though well we may not pass upon his life
Without the form of justice, yet our power
Shall do a court’sy to our wrath, which men
May blame, but not control.
speech.stagedir: Enter Gloucester, brought in by two or three Servants.
speech.line: Who’s there? The traitor?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Ingrateful fox, ’tis he.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Bind fast his corky arms.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: What means your Graces? Good my friends, consider
You are my guests. Do me no foul play, friends.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Bind him, I say.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Hard, hard. O filthy traitor!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Unmerciful lady as you are, I’m none.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: To this chair bind him. Villain, thou shalt find—

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: By the kind gods, ’tis most ignobly done
To pluck me by the beard.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: So white, and such a traitor?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Naughty lady,
These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin
Will quicken and accuse thee. I am your host,
With robber’s hands my hospitable favors
You should not ruffle thus. What will you do?

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Come, sir, what letters had you late from France?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Be simple-answer’d, for we know the truth.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: And what confederacy have you with the traitors
Late footed in the kingdom?

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: To whose hands you have sent the lunatic King—
Speak.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I have a letter guessingly set down,
Which came from one that’s of a neutral heart,
And not from one oppos’d.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Cunning.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: And false.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Where hast thou sent the King?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: To Dover.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Wherefore to Dover? Wast thou not charg’d at peril—

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Wherefore to Dover? Let him answer that.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I am tied to th’ stake, and I must stand the course .

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Wherefore to Dover?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Because I would not see thy cruel nails
Pluck out his poor old eyes, nor thy fierce sister
In his anointed flesh rash boarish fangs.
The sea, with such a storm as his bare head
In hell-black night endur’d, would have buoy’d up
And quench’d the stelled fires;
Yet, poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain.
If wolves had at thy gate howl’d that dearn time,
Thou shouldst have said, “Good porter, turn the key.”
All cruels else subscribe; but I shall see
The winged vengeance overtake such children.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: See’t shalt thou never. Fellows, hold the chair,
Upon these eyes of thine I’ll set my foot.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: He that will think to live till he be old,
Give me some help! O cruel! O you gods!

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: One side will mock another; th’ other too.

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: If you see vengeance—

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: Hold your hand, my lord!
I have serv’d you ever since I was a child;
But better service have I never done you
Than now to bid you hold.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: How now, you dog?

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: If you did wear a beard upon your chin,
I’ld shake it on this quarrel. What do you mean?

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: My villain!

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: Nay then come on, and take the chance of anger.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Give me thy sword. A peasant stand up thus?

scene.stagedir: She takes a sword and runs at him behind; kills him.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: O, I am slain! My lord, you have one eye left
To see some mischief on him. O!

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: Lest it see more, prevent it. Out, vild jelly!
Where is thy lustre now?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: All dark and comfortless! Where’s my son Edmund?
Edmund, enkindle all the sparks of nature,
To quit this horrid act.

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Out, treacherous villain!
Thou call’st on him that hates thee. It was he
That made the overture of thy treasons to us,
Who is too good to pity thee.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: O my follies! Then Edgar was abus’d.
Kind gods, forgive me that, and prosper him!

speech.speaker: REG.
speech.line: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell
His way to Dover.
How is’t, my lord? How look you?

speech.speaker: CORN.
speech.line: I have receiv’d a hurt; follow me, lady.—
Turn out that eyeless villain; throw this slave
Upon the dunghill. Regan, I bleed apace,
Untimely comes this hurt. Give me your arm.

speech.speaker: 2. SERV.
speech.line: I’ll never care what wickedness I do,
If this man come to good.

speech.speaker: 3. SERV.
speech.line: If she live long,
And in the end meet the old course of death,
Women will all turn monsters.

speech.speaker: 2. SERV.
speech.line: Let’s follow the old Earl, and get the Bedlam
To lead him where he would; his roguish madness
Allows itself to any thing.

speech.speaker: 3. SERV.
speech.line: Go thou. I’ll fetch some flax and whites of eggs
To apply to his bleeding face. Now heaven help him!

scene.scenedescription: Edgar meets his blinded father, led by an old tenant of his whom he pushes away, and realizes that things can always get worse. Gloucester has reached a rare depth of despair and utterly lost faith that there is any good in the universe; Edgar overhears him and realizes that his father now knows he was tricked. The old man asks Edgar to lead Gloucester, and he agrees, though uncertain how long he will be able to keep up his pretence of being Poor Tom. Gloucester asks to be led to a high cliff near Dover.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Yet better thus, and known to be contemn’d,
Than still contemn’d and flatter’d. To be worst,
The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune,
Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear.
The lamentable change is from the best,
The worst returns to laughter. Welcome then,
Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace:
The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst
Owes nothing to thy blasts.
speech.stagedir: Enter Gloucester led by an Old Man.
speech.line: But who comes here?
My father, parti-ey’d? World, world, O world!
But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,
Life would not yield to age.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: O my good lord,
I have been your tenant, and your father’s tenant,
These fourscore years.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Away, get thee away! Good friend, be gone,
Thy comforts can do me no good at all;
Thee they may hurt.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: You cannot see your way.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I have no way, and therefore want no eyes;
I stumbled when I saw. Full oft ’tis seen,
Our means secure us, and our mere defects
Prove our commodities. O dear son Edgar,
The food of thy abused father’s wrath!
Might I but live to see thee in my touch,
I’ld say I had eyes again.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: How now? Who’s there?

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: O gods! Who is’t can say, “I am at the worst”?
I am worse than e’er I was.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: ’Tis poor mad Tom.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: And worse I may be yet: the worst is not
So long as we can say, “This is the worst.”

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: Fellow, where goest?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Is it a beggar-man?

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: Madman and beggar too.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: He has some reason, else he could not beg.
I’ th’ last night’s storm I such a fellow saw,
Which made me think a man a worm. My son
Came then into my mind, and yet my mind
Was then scarce friends with him. I have heard more since.
As flies to wanton boys are we to th’ gods,
They kill us for their sport.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: How should this be?
Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow,
Ang’ring itself and others.—Bless thee, master!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Is that the naked fellow?

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: Ay, my lord.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Then prithee get thee away. If for my sake
Thou wilt o’ertake us hence a mile or twain
I’ th’ way toward Dover, do it for ancient love,
And bring some covering for this naked soul,
Which I’ll entreat to lead me.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: Alack, sir, he is mad.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: ’Tis the time’s plague, when madmen lead the blind.
Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleasure;
Above the rest, be gone.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: I’ll bring him the best ’parel that I have,
Come on’t what will.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Sirrah, naked fellow—

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Poor Tom’s a-cold.
I cannot daub it further.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Come hither, fellow.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: And yet I must.—Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Know’st thou the way to Dover?

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Both stile and gate, horse-way and foot-path. Poor Tom hath been scar’d out of his good wits. Bless thee, good man’s son, from the foul fiend! Five fiends have been in poor Tom at once: of lust, as Obidicut; Hobbididence, prince of dumbness; Mahu, of stealing; Modo, of murder; Flibbertigibbet, of mopping and mowing, who since possesses chambermaids and waiting-women. So, bless thee, master!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Here, take this purse, thou whom the heav’ns’ plagues
Have humbled to all strokes. That I am wretched
Makes thee the happier; heavens, deal so still!
Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,
That slaves your ordinance, that will not see
Because he does not feel, feel your pow’r quickly;
So distribution should undo excess,
And each man have enough. Dost thou know Dover?

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Ay, master.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: There is a cliff, whose high and bending head
Looks fearfully in the confined deep.
Bring me but to the very brim of it,
And I’ll repair the misery thou dost bear
With something rich about me. From that place
I shall no leading need.

speech.speaker: EDG.
speech.line: Give me thy arm;
Poor Tom shall lead thee.

scene.scenelocation: Before the Duke of Albany’s palace.
scene.scenedescription: Oswald informs Goneril that her husband’s reaction to the news of recent events is not at all what might have been expected. Goneril blames it on his weakness, and sends Edmund back to Cornwall, to lead his armies. Goneril is quite taken with Edmund, considering him much more of a man than her actual husband. Albany, entering, reveals the extent to which he despises his wife for her treatment of Lear. Goneril reviles him as a wimp. Albany swears he’d kill her were she not a woman. At this point, news comes that Cornwall has died of his wounds. Goneril worries that Regan may gain Edmund’s love, being widowed and thus able to marry him. Albany swears he will revenge Gloucester’s eyes.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: Welcome, my lord. I marvel our mild husband
Not met us on the way.
Now, where’s your master?

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Madam, within, but never man so chang’d.
I told him of the army that was landed;
He smil’d at it. I told him you were coming;
His answer was, “The worse.” Of Gloucester’s treachery,
And of the loyal service of his son,
When I inform’d him, then he call’d me sot,
And told me I had turn’d the wrong side out.
What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him;
What like, offensive.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: Then shall you go no further.
It is the cowish terror of his spirit
That dares not undertake; he’ll not feel wrongs
Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way
May prove effects. Back, Edmund, to my brother,
Hasten his musters and conduct his pow’rs.
I must change names at home, and give the distaff
Into my husband’s hands. This trusty servant
Shall pass between us. Ere long you are like to hear
(If you dare venture in your own behalf)
A mistress’s command. Wear this; spare speech.
Decline your head: this kiss, if it durst speak,
Would stretch thy spirits up into the air.
Conceive, and fare thee well.

speech.speaker: EDM.
speech.line: Yours in the ranks of death.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: My most dear Gloucester!
O, the difference of man and man!
To thee a woman’s services are due,
A fool usurps my bed.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Madam, here comes my lord.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: I have been worth the whistling.

speech.speaker: ALB.
speech.line: O Goneril,
You are not worth the dust which the rude wind
Blows in your face. I fear your disposition;
That nature which contemns it origin
Cannot be bordered certain in itself.
She that herself will sliver and disbranch
From her material sap, perforce must wither,
And come to deadly use.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: No more, the text is foolish.

speech.speaker: ALB.
speech.line: Wisdom and goodness to the vild seem vild,
Filths savor but themselves. What have you done?
Tigers, not daughters, what have you perform’d?
A father, and a gracious aged man,
Whose reverence even the head-lugg’d bear would lick,
Most barbarous, most degenerate, have you madded.
Could my good brother suffer you to do it?
A man, a prince, by him so benefited!
If that the heavens do not their visible spirits
Send quickly down to tame these vild offenses,
It will come,
Humanity must perforce prey on itself,
Like monsters of the deep.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: Milk-liver’d man,
That bear’st a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs,
Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning
Thine honor from thy suffering, that not know’st
Fools do those villains pity who are punish’d
Ere they have done their mischief, where’s thy drum?
France spreads his banners in our noiseless land,
With plumed helm thy state begins to threat,
Whilst thou, a moral fool, sits still and cries,
“Alack, why does he so?”

speech.speaker: ALB.
speech.line: See thyself, devil!
Proper deformity shows not in the fiend
So horrid as in woman.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: O vain fool!

speech.speaker: ALB.
speech.line: Thou changed and self-cover’d thing, for shame
Bemonster not thy feature. Were’t my fitness
To let these hands obey my blood,
They are apt enough to dislocate and tear
Thy flesh and bones. Howe’er thou art a fiend,
A woman’s shape doth shield thee.

speech.speaker: GON.
speech.line: Marry, your manhood mew!

speech.speaker: ALB.
speech.line: What news?

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: O my good lord, the Duke of Cornwall’s dead,
Slain by his servant, going to put out
The other eye of Gloucester.

speech.speaker: ALB.
